2 - include full stack trace

member.summary: The culture name to be used for rendering.

The format for culture names is described in RFC 1766 and at MSDN. Some examples of valid culture names are:
en-US - English (United States)
en-UK - English (United Kingdom)
pl-PL - Polish
ar-SA - Arabic (Saudi Arabia)

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.ASPNetTraceTarget
member.summary: Writes logging messages to the ASP.NET trace.
member.example:
To set up the ASP.NET Trace target in the configuration file, put the following in web.nlog file in your web application directory.
This assumes just one target and a single rule. More configuration options are described here.
To configure the target programmatically, put the following piece of code in your Application_OnStart() handler in Global.asax.cs or some other place that gets executed at the very beginning of your code:
Fully working C# project can be found in the Examples/Targets/Configuration API/ASPNetTrace directory along with usage instructions.
Resulting log entries can be viewed by navigating to http://server/path/Trace.axd.
HTTP Request List:
HTTP Request Details:

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.ASPNetTraceTarget.Write(CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Writes the specified logging event to the ASP.NET Trace facility. Log entries can then be viewed by navigating to http://server/path/Trace.axd If the log level is greater than or equal to it uses the method, otherwise it uses method.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LayoutRenderers.SpecialFolderLayoutRenderer.Folder
member.summary: System special folder.
member.remarks:
Full list of options is available at MSDN. The most common ones are:
ApplicationData - roaming application data for current user.
CommonApplicationData - application data for all users.
MyDocuments - My Documents
DesktopDirectory - Desktop directory
LocalApplicationData - non roaming application data
Personal - user profile directory
System - System directory

member.summary: Abstract interface that layouts must implement.

member.summary: Renders the layout for the specified logging event by invoking layout renderers.
member.returns: The rendered layout.

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.ILayout.NeedsStackTrace
member.summary: Returns the value indicating whether a stack trace and/or the source file information should be gathered during layout processing.
member.returns:
0 - don't include stack trace
1 - include stack trace without source file information
2 - include full stack trace

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.ILayout.IsVolatile
member.summary: Returns the value indicating whether this layout includes any volatile layout renderers.
member.returns: when the layout includes at least one volatile renderer, otherwise.
member.remarks: Volatile layout renderers are dependent on information not contained in (such as thread-specific data, MDC data, NDC data).

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.ILayout.Precalculate(CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Precalculates the layout for the specified log event and stores the result in per-log event cache.
member.remarks: Calling this method enables you to store the log event in a buffer and/or potentially evaluate it in another thread even though the layout may contain thread-dependent renderer.

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.AsyncTargetWrapper
member.summary: A target wrapper that provides asynchronous, buffered execution of target writes.

remarks.p: Asynchronous target wrapper allows the logger code to execute more quickly, by queueing messages and processing them in a separate thread. You should wrap targets that spend a non-trivial amount of time in their Write() method with asynchronous target to speed up logging.

Because asynchronous logging is quite a common scenario, NLog supports a shorthand notation for wrapping all targets with AsyncWrapper. Just add async="true" to the <targets/> element in the configuration file.

example.p: To set up the target in the configuration file, use the following syntax:
The above examples assume just one target and a single rule. See below for a programmatic configuration that's equivalent to the above config file:

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LayoutRenderers.ASPNETApplicationValueLayoutRenderer

member.remarks: Use this layout renderer to insert the value of the specified variable stored in the ASP.NET Application dictionary.

example.para: You can set the value of an ASP.NET Application variable by using the following code:
example.code: ${aspnet-application:variable=myvariable} - produces "123" ${aspnet-application:variable=anothervariable} - produces "01/01/2006 00:00:00" ${aspnet-application:variable=anothervariable:culture=pl-PL} - produces "2006-01-01 00:00:00" ${aspnet-application:variable=myvariable:padding=5} - produces " 123" ${aspnet-application:variable=myvariable:padding=-5} - produces "123 " ${aspnet-application:variable=stringvariable:upperCase=true} - produces "AAA BBB"

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.RetryingTargetWrapper
member.summary: A target wrapper that causes retries on wrapped target errors.

example.p: This example causes each write attempt to be repeated 3 times, sleeping 1 second between attempts if first one fails.
To set up the target in the configuration file, use the following syntax:
The above examples assume just one target and a single rule. See below for a programmatic configuration that's equivalent to the above config file:

member.summary: Writes the specified log event to the wrapped target, retrying and pausing in case of an error.

member.summary: Number of retries that should be attempted on the wrapped target in case of a failure.

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.PostFilteringTargetWrapper
member.summary: A target wrapper that filters buffered log entries based on a set of conditions that are evaluated on all events.
member.remarks: PostFilteringWrapper must be used with some type of buffering target or wrapper, such as AsyncTargetWrapper, BufferingWrapper or ASPNetBufferingWrapper.

example.p: This example works like this. If there are no Warn,Error or Fatal messages in the buffer only Info messages are written to the file, but if there are any warnings or errors, the output includes detailed trace (levels >= Debug). You can plug in a different type of buffering wrapper (such as ASPNetBufferingWrapper) to achieve different functionality.
To set up the target in the configuration file, use the following syntax:
The above examples assume just one target and a single rule. See below for a programmatic configuration that's equivalent to the above config file:

member.summary: Creates a new instance of .

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.PostFilteringTargetWrapper.Write(CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LogEventInfo[])
member.summary: Evaluates all filtering rules to find the first one that matches. The matching rule determines the filtering condition to be applied to all items in a buffer. If no condition matches, default filter is applied to the array of log events.
member.param: Array of log events to be post-filtered.

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.PostFilteringTargetWrapper.Write(CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Processes a single log event. Not very useful for this post-filtering wrapper.

member.summary: Adds all layouts used by this target to the specified collection.
member.param: The collection to add layouts to.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.PostFilteringTargetWrapper.DefaultFilter
member.summary: Default filter to be applied when no specific rule matches.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.PostFilteringTargetWrapper.Rules
member.summary: Collection of filtering rules. The rules are processed top-down and the first rule that matches determines the filtering condition to be applied to log events.

1 - include stack trace without source file information
2 - include full stack trace

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.ASPNetBufferingTargetWrapper
member.summary: A target that buffers log events for the duration of the ASP.NET Request and sends them down to the wrapped target as soon as the request ends.

remarks.p: Typically this target is used in cooperation with PostFilteringTargetWrapper to provide verbose logging for failing requests and normal or no logging for successful requests. We need to make the decision of the final filtering rule to apply after all logs for a page have been generated.
To use this target, you need to add an entry in the httpModules section of web.config:

example.p: To set up the ASP.NET Buffering target wrapper configuration file, put the following in web.nlog file in your web application directory (this assumes that PostFilteringWrapper is used to provide the filtering and actual logs go to a file).
This assumes just one target and a single rule. More configuration options are described here.

To configure the target programmatically, put the following piece of code in your Application_OnStart() handler in Global.asax.cs or some other place that gets executed at the very beginning of your code:
Fully working C# project can be found in the Examples/Targets/Configuration API/ASPNetBufferingWrapper directory along with usage instructions.

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.NLogViewerTarget
member.summary: Sends logging messages to the remote instance of NLog Viewer.

example.p: To set up the target in the configuration file, use the following syntax:
This assumes just one target and a single rule. More configuration options are described here.
To set up the log target programmatically use code like this:

NOTE: If your receiver application is ever likely to be off-line, don't use TCP protocol or you'll get TCP timeouts and your application will crawl. Either switch to UDP transport or use AsyncWrapper target so that your application threads will not be blocked by the timing-out connection attempts.

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.NetworkTarget
member.summary: Sends logging messages over the network.

example.p: To set up the target in the configuration file, use the following syntax:
This assumes just one target and a single rule. More configuration options are described here.
To set up the log target programmatically use code like this:

To print the results, use any application that's able to receive messages over TCP or UDP. NetCat is a simple but very powerful command-line tool that can be used for that. This image demonstrates the NetCat tool receiving log messages from Network target.

NOTE: If your receiver application is ever likely to be off-line, don't use TCP protocol or you'll get TCP timeouts and your application will crawl. Either switch to UDP transport or use AsyncWrapper target so that your application threads will not be blocked by the timing-out connection attempts.
There are two specialized versions of the Network target: Chainsaw and NLogViewer which write to instances of Chainsaw log4j viewer or NLogViewer application respectively.

To set up the log target programmatically use code like this (an equivalent of MSSQL configuration):

member.summary: The database name. If the ConnectionString is not provided this value will be used to construct the "Database=" part of the connection string.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.DatabaseTarget.CommandText
member.summary: The text of the SQL command to be run on each log level.
member.remarks: Typically this is a SQL INSERT statement or a stored procedure call. It should use the database-specific parameters (marked as @parameter for SQL server or :parameter for Oracle, other data providers have their own notation) and not the layout renderers, because the latter is prone to SQL injection attacks. The layout renderers should be specified as <parameters />> instead.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.DatabaseTarget.CommandTextLayout
member.summary: The text of the SQL command to be run on each log level.
member.remarks: Typically this is a SQL INSERT statement or a stored procedure call. It should use the database-specific parameters (marked as @parameter for SQL server or :parameter for Oracle, other data providers have their own notation) and not the layout renderers, because the latter is prone to SQL injection attacks. The layout renderers should be specified as <parameters />< instead.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.DatabaseTarget.Parameters
member.summary: The collection of paramters. Each parameter contains a mapping between NLog layout and a database named or positional parameter.

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Compound.RoundRobinTarget
member.summary: A compound target that forwards writes to the sub-targets in a round-robin fashion.

example.p: This example causes the messages to be written to either file1.txt or file2.txt. Each odd message is written to file2.txt, each even message goes to file1.txt.
To set up the target in the configuration file, use the following syntax:
The above examples assume just one target and a single rule. See below for a programmatic configuration that's equivalent to the above config file:

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Compound.RoundRobinTarget.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of .

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Compound.RoundRobinTarget.#ctor(CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Target[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of and initializes the collection to the provided array of objects.

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Compound.RoundRobinTarget.Write(CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Forwards the write to one of the targets from the collection.
member.remarks: The writes are routed in a round-robin fashion. The first log event goes to the first target, the second one goes to the second target and so on looping to the first target when there are no more targets available. In general request N goes to Targets[N % Targets.Count].

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LoggerReconfiguredDelegate
member.summary: Represents a method that's invoked each time a configuration changes.
member.remarks: 'Reconfiguring' a logger means rebuilding the list of targets and filters that will be invoked on logging. This may or may not influence the result returned by IsXXXXEnabled properties.

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Layout.NeedsStackTrace
member.summary: Returns the value indicating whether a stack trace and/or the source file information should be gathered during layout processing.
member.returns:
0 - don't include stack trace
1 - include stack trace without source file information
2 - include full stack trace

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Layout.IsVolatile
member.summary: Returns the value indicating whether this layout includes any volatile layout renderers.
member.returns: when the layout includes at least one volatile renderer, otherwise.
member.remarks: Volatile layout renderers are dependent on information not contained in (such as thread-specific data, MDC data, NDC data).

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Layout.Precalculate(CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Precalculates the layout for the specified log event and stores the result in per-log event cache.
member.remarks: Calling this method enables you to store the log event in a buffer and/or potentially evaluate it in another thread even though the layout may contain thread-dependent renderer.

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Layout.Escape(System.String)
member.summary: Escapes the passed text so that it can be used literally in all places where layout is normally expected without being treated as layout.
member.returns: The escaped text.
member.remarks: Escaping is done by replacing all occurences of '${' with '${literal:text=${}'

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Layout.Evaluate(System.String,CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Evaluates the specified text by expadinging all layout renderers.
member.param: Log event to be used for evaluation
member.returns: The input text with all occurences of ${} replaced with values provided by the appropriate layout renderers.

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Layout.Evaluate(System.String)
member.summary: Evaluates the specified text by expadinging all layout renderers in new context.
member.returns: The input text with all occurences of ${} replaced with values provided by the appropriate layout renderers.

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Internal.FileAppenders.MutexMultiProcessFileAppender
member.summary: Provides a multiprocess-safe atomic file appends while keeping the files open.
member.remarks: On Unix you can get all the appends to be atomic, even when multiple processes are trying to write to the same file, because setting the file pointer to the end of the file and appending can be made one operation. On Win32 we need to maintain some synchronization between processes (global named mutex is used for this)

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.ImpersonatingTargetWrapper.SecurityLogonType
member.summary: Logon type.

member.name: F:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.ImpersonatingTargetWrapper.SecurityLogonType.Interactive
member.summary: Interactive Logon
member.remarks: This logon type is intended for users who will be interactively using the computer, such as a user being logged on by a terminal server, remote shell, or similar process. This logon type has the additional expense of caching logon information for disconnected operations; therefore, it is inappropriate for some client/server applications, such as a mail server.

member.name: F:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.ImpersonatingTargetWrapper.SecurityLogonType.Network
member.summary: Network Logon
member.remarks: This logon type is intended for high performance servers to authenticate plaintext passwords. The LogonUser function does not cache credentials for this logon type.

member.name: F:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.ImpersonatingTargetWrapper.SecurityLogonType.Batch
member.summary: Batch Logon
member.remarks: This logon type is intended for batch servers, where processes may be executing on behalf of a user without their direct intervention. This type is also for higher performance servers that process many plaintext authentication attempts at a time, such as mail or Web servers. The LogonUser function does not cache credentials for this logon type.

member.name: F:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.ImpersonatingTargetWrapper.SecurityLogonType.Service
member.summary: Logon as a Service
member.remarks: Indicates a service-type logon. The account provided must have the service privilege enabled.

member.name: F:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.ImpersonatingTargetWrapper.SecurityLogonType.NetworkClearText
member.summary: Network Clear Text Logon
member.remarks: This logon type preserves the name and password in the authentication package, which allows the server to make connections to other network servers while impersonating the client. A server can accept plaintext credentials from a client, call LogonUser, verify that the user can access the system across the network, and still communicate with other servers. NOTE: Windows NT: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.ImpersonatingTargetWrapper.SecurityLogonType.NewCredentials
member.summary: New Network Credentials
member.remarks: This logon type allows the caller to clone its current token and specify new credentials for outbound connections. The new logon session has the same local identifier but uses different credentials for other network connections. NOTE: This logon type is supported only by the LOGON32_PROVIDER_WINNT50 logon provider. NOTE: Windows NT: This value is not supported.

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.ImpersonatingTargetWrapper.LogonProviderType
member.summary: Logon provider.

member.name: F:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.Wrappers.ImpersonatingTargetWrapper.LogonProviderType.Default
member.summary: Use the standard logon provider for the system.
member.remarks: The default security provider is negotiate, unless you pass NULL for the domain name and the user name is not in UPN format. In this case, the default provider is NTLM. NOTE: Windows 2000/NT: The default security provider is NTLM.

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.LayoutRenderers.ASPNETSessionValueLayoutRenderer
member.summary: ASP.NET Session variable.
member.remarks: Use this layout renderer to insert the value of the specified variable stored in the ASP.NET Session dictionary.

example.para: You can set the value of an ASP.NET Session variable by using the following code:
example.code: ${aspnet-session:variable=myvariable} - produces "123" ${aspnet-session:variable=anothervariable} - produces "01/01/2006 00:00:00" ${aspnet-session:variable=anothervariable:culture=pl-PL} - produces "2006-01-01 00:00:00" ${aspnet-session:variable=myvariable:padding=5} - produces " 123" ${aspnet-session:variable=myvariable:padding=-5} - produces "123 " ${aspnet-session:variable=stringvariable:upperCase=true} - produces "AAA BBB"

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Win32.Targets.ColoredConsoleTarget
member.summary: Writes logging messages to the console with customizable coloring.

example.p: To set up the target in the configuration file, use the following syntax:
This assumes just one target and a single rule. More configuration options are described here.
To set up the log target programmatically use code like this:
The result is a colorful console, where each color represents a single log level.
In addition you can configure your own word highlighting rules so that particular words or regular expressions will be marked with a distinguished color:
Programmatic equivalent of the above configuration:
Here's the result:

Custom row highlighting lets you colorize the output by any condition. This example shows how to mark all entries containing the word "serious" with white color on red background and mark all entries coming from a particular logger with yellow on blue.
Programmatic equivalent of the above configuration:
Here's the result:

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Win32.Targets.ColoredConsoleTarget.UseDefaultRowHighlightingRules
member.summary: Use default row highlighting rules.
member.remarks:
The default rules are:
Condition Foreground Color Background Color
level == LogLevel.Fatal Red NoChange
level == LogLevel.Error Yellow NoChange
level == LogLevel.Warn Magenta NoChange
level == LogLevel.Info White NoChange
level == LogLevel.Debug Gray NoChange
level == LogLevel.Trace DarkGray NoChange

member.name: T:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget
member.summary: Writes logging messages to one or more files.

example.p: To set up the target in the configuration file, use the following syntax:

You can use a single target to write to multiple files. The following example writes each log message to a file named after its log level, so it will create: Trace.log, Debug.log, Info.log, Warn.log, Error.log, Fatal.log

The file names can be quite complex for the most demanding scenarios. This example shows a way to create separate files for each day, user and log level. As you can see, the possibilities are endless.

Depending on your usage scenario it may be useful to add an asynchronous target wrapper around the file target. This way all your log messages will be written in a separate thread so your main thread can finish your work more quickly. Asynchronous logging is recommended for multi-threaded server applications which run for a long time and is not recommended for quickly-finishing command line applications.
The above examples assume just one target and a single rule. See below for a programmatic configuration that's equivalent to the above config file:
More configuration options are described here.
To set up the log target programmatically use code like this:

File target can also do file archiving, meaning that the log file is automatically moved to another place based on its size and time. This example demonstrates file archiving based on size. Files after 10000 bytes are moved to a separate folder and renamed log.00000.txt, log.00001.txt and so on.
File archiving can also be done on date/time changes. For example, to create a new archive file every minute use this code:
You can combine both methods as demonstrated here:
Note that file archiving works even when you use a single target instance to write to multiple files, such as putting each log level in a separate place:
You can write texts using alternative layouts, such as CSV (comma-separated values). This example writes files which are properly CSV-quoted (can handle messages with line breaks and quotes)
example.para: This is the configuration file version:

member.summary: Removes records of initialized files that have not been accessed in the last two days.
member.remarks: Files are marked 'initialized' for the purpose of writing footers when the logging finishes.

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.Flush(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Flushes all pending file operations.
member.remarks: The timeout parameter is ignored, because file APIs don't provide the needed functionality.

member.name: M:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.Close
member.summary: Closes the file(s) opened for writing.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.FileName
member.summary: The name of the file to write to.
member.remarks: This FileName string is a layout which may include instances of layout renderers. This lets you use a single target to write to multiple files.
member.example: The following value makes NLog write logging events to files based on the log level in the directory where the application runs. ${basedir}/${level}.log All Debug messages will go to Debug.log, all Info messages will go to Info.log and so on. You can combine as many of the layout renderers as you want to produce an arbitrary log file name.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.CreateDirs
member.summary: Create directories if they don't exist.
member.remarks: Setting this to false may improve performance a bit, but you'll receive an error when attempting to write to a directory that's not present.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.OpenFileCacheSize
member.summary: The number of files to be kept open. Setting this to a higher value may improve performance in a situation where a single File target is writing to many files (such as splitting by level or by logger).
member.remarks: The files are managed on a LRU (least recently used) basis, which flushes the files that have not been used for the longest period of time should the cache become full. As a rule of thumb, you shouldn't set this parameter to a very high value. A number like 10-15 shouldn't be exceeded, because you'd be keeping a large number of files open which consumes system resources.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.OpenFileCacheTimeout
member.summary: Maximum number of seconds that files are kept open. If this number is negative.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.DeleteOldFileOnStartup
member.summary: Delete old log file on startup.
member.remarks: This option works only when the "fileName" parameter denotes a single file.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.ReplaceFileContentsOnEachWrite
member.summary: Replace file contents on each write instead of appending log message at the end.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.KeepFileOpen
member.summary: Keep log file open instead of opening and closing it on each logging event.
member.remarks: Setting this property to True helps improve performance.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.EnableFileDelete
member.summary: Enable log file(s) to be deleted.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.FileAttributes

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.NewLineChars

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.LineEnding
member.summary: Line ending mode.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.AutoFlush
member.summary: Automatically flush the file buffers after each log message.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.BufferSize
member.summary: Log file buffer size in bytes.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.Encoding
member.summary: File encoding.
member.remarks: Can be any encoding name supported by System.Text.Encoding.GetEncoding() e.g. windows-1252, iso-8859-2.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.ConcurrentWrites
member.summary: Enables concurrent writes to the log file by multiple processes on the same host.
member.remarks: This makes multi-process logging possible. NLog uses a special technique that lets it keep the files open for writing.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.NetworkWrites
member.summary: Disables open-fi

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.ConcurrentWriteAttempts
member.summary: The number of times the write is appended on the file before NLog discards the log message.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.ArchiveAboveSize
member.summary: Automatically archive log files that exceed the specified size in bytes.
member.remarks: Caution: Enabling this option can considerably slow down your file logging in multi-process scenarios. If only one process is going to be writing to the file, consider setting ConcurrentWrites to false for maximum performance.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.ArchiveEvery
member.summary: Automatically archive log files every time the specified time passes. Possible options are: year, month, day, hour, minute. Files are moved to the archive as part of the write operation if the current period of time changes. For example if the current hour changes from 10 to 11, the first write that will occur on or after 11:00 will trigger the archiving.

remarks.p: Caution: Enabling this option can considerably slow down your file logging in multi-process scenarios. If only one process is going to be writing to the file, consider setting ConcurrentWrites to false for maximum performance.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.ArchiveFileName
member.summary: The name of the file to be used for an archive. It may contain a special placeholder {#####} that will be replaced with a sequence of numbers depending on the archiving strategy. The number of hash characters used determines the number of numerical digits to be used for numbering files.

member.name: P:CSLibrary.Diagnostics.Targets.FileTarget.ConcurrentWriteAttemptDelay
member.summary: The delay in milliseconds to wait before attempting to write to the file again.
member.remarks: The actual delay is a random value between 0 and the value specified in this parameter. On each failed attempt the delay base is doubled up to times.
member.example:
Assuming that ConcurrentWriteAttemptDelay is 10 the time to wait will be:
a random value between 0 and 10 milliseconds - 1st attempt
a random value between 0 and 20 milliseconds - 2nd attempt
a random value between 0 and 40 milliseconds - 3rd attempt
a random value between 0 and 80 milliseconds - 4th attempt
...
and so on.

example.p: To set up the target in the configuration file, use the following syntax:
This assumes just one target and a single rule. More configuration options are described here.
To set up the log target programmatically use code like this:

NOTE: If your receiver application is ever likely to be off-line, don't use TCP protocol or you'll get TCP timeouts and your application will crawl. Either switch to UDP transport or use AsyncWrapper target so that your application threads will not be blocked by the timing-out connection attempts.
